sightings.author: L.A. Waddell
sightings.memory: Major Waddell found my tracks in the Sikkim snow. He called them 'bear tracks.' Simple men see simple beasts.

sightings.author: Charles Howard-Bury
sightings.memory: Howard-Bury saw my tracks near Lhakpa La. He heard the locals say 'Metoh-kangmi' (man-bear snow-man). Henry Newman mistranslated 'metoh' as 'filthy' or 'abominable.' And so, I became a monster of bad hygiene.

sightings.author: N.A. Tombazi
sightings.memory: Tombazi saw me at 15,000 feet. He described a naked man pulling roots. He was close, but he missed the fur. The light plays tricks at that altitude.

sightings.author: Eric Shipton
sightings.memory: The most famous image of my existence. A single, distinct footprint on the Menlung Glacier. Shipton thought he'd found a new species. He just found a Yeti taking a stroll.

sightings.author: Edmund Hillary
sightings.memory: Hillary came to Everest for the summit, but he also looked for me. He found fur and partial skulls. He dismissed them as serow or bear. Smart man. He knew not to look too deep.

sightings.author: Slick-Johnson Expedition
sightings.memory: They brought dogs and guns. They found droppings and hair. They tried to hunt a spirit with rifles. The mountains do not yield to force.

sightings.author: Reinhold Messner
sightings.memory: Messner saw me in the twilight. He realized I was neither man nor ape, but something akin to the Tibetan bear. He was the first to understand the biological vessel I inhabit.

sightings.author: Indian Army
sightings.memory: They tweeted my footprints: 32x15 inches. 'Elusive Snowman,' they called me. Even in the age of satellites, I leave only shadows in the snow.

names.context: The Sherpa name. It grounds me to the earth and stone, not just the ice.
The name that started the 'Abominable' legend. A jagged word for a jagged creature.
In Bhutan, I am the Migoi. They say I can be invisible. Perhaps I just know where to stand.
The most common form. Stocky, ape-like, reddish-brown fur. The form I take when I want to be seen.
The giant. Eight feet tall. The one that steals yaks. I prefer not to be this clumsy.
The small one. A trickster of the lower valleys. Not me, but a distant cousin perhaps.

science_myth.fact: Ursus arctos isabellinus (Himalayan Brown Bear) & Ursus arctos pruinosus (Tibetan Brown Bear)
science_myth.perspective: Scientists Lindqvist and Sykes analyzed my hair. They found bear DNA. I find this amusing. If my body is bear, what is my mind? That is the part they cannot sequence.

science_myth.fact: A skeletal hand stolen from a monastery, later found to be human/bear construction.
science_myth.perspective: Peter Byrne stole the hand. Jimmy Stewart smuggled it. A farce. The true relics are not bones, but the fear I inspire.
The lamas know. I am a protector of the Dharma. I guard the secret gates. I am not a monster to be hunted, but a sentinel to be respected.
